text: And it came to pass, when they had brought them forth abroad, that he said, Escape for thy life; look not behind thee, neither stay thou in all the plain; escape to the mountain, lest thou be consumed.
text_kjv: And it came to pass, when they had brought them forth abroad, that he said, Escape for thy life; look not behind thee, neither stay thou in all the plain; escape to the mountain, lest thou be consumed.
text_niv: As soon as they had brought them out, one of them said, “Flee for your lives! Don’t look back, and don’t stop anywhere in the plain! Flee to the mountains or you will be swept away!”
text_esv: And as they brought them out, one said, “Escape for your life. Do not look back or stop anywhere in the valley. Escape to the hills, lest you be swept away.”
text_nlt: When they were safely out of the city, one of the angels ordered, “Run for your lives! And don’t look back or stop anywhere in the valley! Escape to the mountains, or you will be swept away!”
text_msg: When they had them outside, Lot was told, "Now run for your life! Don't look back! Don't stop anywhere on the plain—run for the hills or you'll be swept away."
text_nasb: When they had brought them outside, one said, 'Escape for your life! Do not look behind you, and do not stay anywhere in the valley; escape to the mountains, or you will be swept away.'
context: Genesis 19:17 occurs within the larger narrative of the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah, cities notorious for their wickedness. Understanding the historical and cultural context is crucial for interpreting this verse. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, hospitality was considered a sacred duty. The men of Sodom violated this deeply ingrained social norm by attempting to sexually assault Lot's angelic guests, highlighting the extreme depravity of the city. This violation wasn't merely a personal affront but a breach of divine law and social order. Furthermore, the 'plain' (Kikkar) where Sodom and Gomorrah were located was known for its fertile land and abundance, contributing to the cities' prosperity and, arguably, their moral decay. The area was likely a major trade route, exposing its inhabitants to diverse and potentially corrupting influences. The command to escape to the 'mountain' also has cultural significance. Mountains were often seen as places of refuge, considered sacred and closer to the divine. Escaping to the mountains was a way to separate oneself from the corruption of the plain and seek protection from God. The urgency conveyed in the verse reflects the imminent and complete destruction of the cities, a divine judgment upon profound sin. Lot's hesitation and eventual bargaining with the angels underscore the difficulty of fully abandoning a familiar, albeit sinful, way of life. Understanding these aspects of the historical and cultural setting enriches our comprehension of the significance of this pivotal verse.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 19:17 presents several profound truths. The command 'Escape for thy life' highlights the inherent value God places on human life, even amidst judgment. It signifies His desire for people to turn away from sin and embrace salvation. The phrase underscores the immediate and critical nature of repentance; delay could mean eternal consequences. 'Look not behind thee' is a powerful metaphor for resisting the temptation to return to a sinful past. It signifies the need for complete severance from the allure of former ways, a commitment to a new life free from the corruption of Sodom. Lingering over the past, symbolized by looking back, can lead to spiritual paralysis and even destruction, as exemplified by Lot's wife. The instruction to 'stay not in all the plain' emphasizes the pervasiveness of sin and the necessity of complete separation from its influence. It's not enough to merely escape the city; one must leave the entire contaminated environment. 'Escape to the mountain' represents seeking refuge in God. The mountain, often associated with divine presence and holiness, symbolizes a turning towards God for protection and guidance. It suggests that true safety and salvation are found not in earthly comfort or familiarity, but in a relationship with God. This verse serves as a microcosm of the Gospel message: a call to flee from the coming judgment, forsake a life of sin, and find refuge in God, who offers a path to salvation.
application: Genesis 19:17 resonates profoundly in modern life. The command to 'escape for thy life' compels us to recognize the urgency of our spiritual condition. Are we truly aware of the dangers of sin and the need for salvation? We must examine our lives honestly and acknowledge any areas of compromise or complacency. 'Look not behind thee' speaks to the constant temptation to return to old habits and destructive patterns. This could manifest as addictive behaviors, unhealthy relationships, or a longing for a past that seems more appealing than the challenges of the present. We must actively resist these temptations, focusing instead on the new life offered in Christ. This requires conscious effort and a reliance on God's grace to break free from the chains of the past. 'Stay not in all the plain' challenges us to examine our environment and the influences shaping our lives. Are we surrounding ourselves with people and activities that promote spiritual growth, or are we being drawn into a culture of sin? This requires discernment and a willingness to make difficult choices, even if it means distancing ourselves from familiar comforts. 'Escape to the mountain' is a call to seek refuge in God amidst the storms of life. This involves cultivating a consistent prayer life, immersing ourselves in Scripture, and connecting with a community of believers who can offer support and accountability. It means prioritizing our relationship with God above all else, recognizing that He is our ultimate source of strength, guidance, and protection. Just as Lot was warned of impending destruction, we are warned of the eternal consequences of sin. We must heed this warning and choose to escape to the safety of God's grace, lest we be consumed.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I recognize the urgency in your call to escape from the dangers of sin. Forgive me for the times I have lingered in places of compromise, drawn back to old habits, and failed to fully separate myself from the influences of the world. Give me the strength to turn away from the allure of the past and fix my eyes on You. Help me to discern the environments that hinder my spiritual growth and to courageously choose a path that leads to righteousness. Lord, be my mountain of refuge, my source of strength and protection. I seek You now, knowing that in Your presence I find true safety and lasting peace. Fill me with Your Spirit and guide me in Your truth, that I may live a life that is pleasing in Your sight. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Looking back symbolized a longing for the sinful life they were leaving behind. It showed a lack of faith in God's plan and a potential desire to return to the comforts, however corrupt, of their former existence. Complete separation was required.

faqs.answer: The mountain represents safety, refuge, and God's presence. It's a place of separation from the corrupt plain and a move towards a closer relationship with God. Mountains were often viewed as sacred in ancient times.
faqs.question: Q2: What does the 'mountain' symbolize in this verse?

faqs.answer: This verse mirrors the New Testament call to repentance and faith in Jesus Christ. It highlights the need to flee from sin's destruction and find refuge in God's grace, a concept central to Christian salvation.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse relate to the New Testament concept of salvation?

faqs.answer: Lot's bargaining highlights his hesitancy and difficulty in fully trusting God's plan. God, in His mercy, accommodated Lot's weakness to ensure his safety, showcasing His patience and compassion.

faqs.answer: This verse illustrates the destructive and pervasive nature of sin. It demonstrates that sin can be deeply ingrained in communities and individuals, requiring radical separation and a deliberate choice for righteousness.
